laboratory_examinations.findings: Normal white cell count of 6460 on initial admission, decreased to 3830 on the 3rd day, and further decreased to 3400 when transferred to this hospital.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: White cell count decreased from 6460 on the first evaluation to 3400 by the third day.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Culture of the skin revealed a heavy growth of Staphylococcus aureus.
Yellow turbid fluid with 2+ ketones and albumin, 3 to 5 red cells, 5 to 10 white cells per high-power field; otherwise normal.
Blood cultures were sterile initially, but later revealed Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Sterile initially, grew Pseudomonas aeruginosa later indicating progression to infection.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Initial hematocrit at 37.6%, decreased to 35.2% on the third day.
Initially at 13.1 g/dl, decreased to 12.2 g/dl on the 3rd day, and rose slightly to 12.4 g/dl on transfer.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: Decreased from 13.1 g/dl to 12.2 g/dl and then increased slightly to 12.4 g/dl.

laboratory_examinations.findings: C-reactive protein was elevated at 239.2 mg/liter.
Sodium was low at 131 mmol/liter, chloride was low at 95 mmol/liter, calcium was low at 7.9 mg/dl, and phosphorus was low at 2.2 mg/dl.
